title: Research how to improve how a "budget" value can be set for each bot instance.

labels.name: research / design
labels.description: Related to research and design performed during off sprint

labels.name: strategy
labels.description: Strategies ideas

body:
## Details
Based on community feedback, investigate how to better make use of different asset allocations across multiple bots instances
![Screen!UNITO-UNDERSCORE!Shot!UNITO-UNDERSCORE!2021-07-28!UNITO-UNDERSCORE!at!UNITO-UNDERSCORE!2.32.16!UNITO-UNDERSCORE!PM.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5f64254ca13ff3717cc3a0c5/ddd00f57-4a31-4cd8-94fe-5efeb438a41e)

Currently, the only way to define how funds are used across different bots is using the `balance limit` command.

Effectively, this method imposes a limit for each instance what is the maximum amount that instance can "spend", but when more than one instance uses a similar asset, it isn't possible to track how each instance is using the available balance.

![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5f64254ca13ff3717cc3a0c5/c6229a93-04bb-487b-8d76-b40bb7f3520a)

This creates conflict between each instance as trades started to be filled.

The way each instance handle the funds should be isolated, separating a"budget" for each instance:

![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5f64254ca13ff3717cc3a0c5/6da43ad3-68ae-4356-848c-0a592f0ea670)

Possible solution:

* The "budget size" should be defined as the total value of both assets that are being traded, not only a "spending limit" for each asset
  * `rate_oracle` can be used to define this value
  * user would define what is the monetary unit the value of the pair would be tracked
  * the value allocated to the instance would be fixed on the chosen monetary value
    * i.e: balance: 10,000 USDT, 1 BTC, BTC price 50,000
    * Monetary unit: USD
    * Total balance value = 10000 + 1 * 50,000 = 60,000
    * Instance Budget = 20,000
    * The instance would only use a total value = instance budget, with the maximum allowed to be used by the instance between two states: 
      * 100% USDT - (20,000 USDT, 0 BTC) -> Even though there would still exist 0.8 BTC on the exchange balance, the instance wouldn't touch it because the total value allocated reached it's maximum
    * 100% BTC - (0 USDT, 0.4 BTC) -> Even if more USDT is added manually to the exchange balance, the instance wouldn't consider it's existence, since the total value allocated is reached
      * Anything in between these two states

The design needs more discussion, and more other options on how this budget is controlled should be explored.

## Definiton of done
* [ ] Research doc of possible ways the different instances can manage an unique balance on the same exchange.

title: Max Order Age - Orders are not created immediately after cancelling orders
body:
**Describe the bug**
When running the avellaneda market making strategy, orders are not created immediately afterwards when max order age is reached. This only happens when order refresh tolerance is enabled and the orders are retained (not canceled) because it didn't reach the value set on `order_refresh_tolerance_pct`. This issue doesn't affect hanging orders that reaches the max order age and other strategies as well.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64377055/127443608-0b8fdc75-f191-4f6c-bb31-4e14715d1ea9.png)

**Steps To Reproduce**

1. Create and run an avellaneda market making strategy.
1. On my test, I set the order_refresh_time to 30, max_order_age to 60 and order_refresh_tolerance_pct to 1 to easily reproduce the issue.
1. When there are no spread changes above or below 1%, orders are retained and max order age will cancel the orders, however it will not create new set of orders immediately and will wait until the next cycle before placing new set of orders.

**Release version**
dev-0.42.0

**Attachments**
Logs and config: [avellaneda.zip](https://github.com/CoinAlpha/hummingbot/files/6898467/avellaneda.zip)

title: Refactor existing strategies to use the new `notify(msg: str)`

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Rewrite / restructure source code without affecting its behavior

body:
**Feature Suggestion**
Add an extra function to HummingbotLogger called `notify(msg: str)`, it logs the message to log file and displays (notifies) the message on the top left screen panel. If user set up Telegram bot, they will get this message on their Telegram as well.

**Impact**
This allows for anywhere in our code base to be able to notify user. For example, when the API rate limit is about to reach, a notification message will be sent to the user (from the throttler), the user can then stop and readjust their strategy parameters.

**Implications**
Since this is a better way of sending a notification, all strategies that currently send notifications through `notify_hb_app` or `notify_hb_app_with_timestamp` should be updated to reflect this.

title: Create inventory balancer strategy addition

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

labels.name: strategy
labels.description: Strategies ideas

body:
**Feature Suggestion**
I would like to have the ability to have a bot (particularly a liquidity mining bot) place orders after both a certain delay and under a certain volatility level.

Ideally, this would have the following configuration options:

* min_delay: [seconds]
* max_volatility_pct: [percent]
* volatility_period: [seconds]
* polling_rate: [seconds]
* min_delay: [seconds] - The minimum number of seconds after a filled order before the bot will take any action, so that I will have the chance to buy or sell the expanded inventory at more advantageous prices
* max_volatility_pct: [percent], volatility_period: [seconds] and polling_rate: [seconds] - Once the min_delay has passed, I would like the bot to begin taking measurements of the volatility in the given pair. This would occur every {polling_rate}, and would calculate the volatility of a pair over the length of the configured {volatility_period}. If the calculated volatility is below the {max_volatility_pct}, the bot would begin to try and balance my inventory to a specified degree.

**In all cases, the below only occurs in the following conditions**

* The {min_delay} + at least one {volatility_period} has passed
* The volatility observed in the configured {volatility_period} is less than the configured {max_volatility_pct}

_Minimum viable design_

* has the following configuration options:
* min_base_asset_amt: [amount]
* min_quote_asset_amt: [amount]
* quote_sell_amt: [amount]
* quote_buy_amt: [amount]
* IF the current base asset amount is below my configured {min_base_asset_amt}, the bot will place a Sell Taker order to exchange {quote_sell_amount} of the quote asset for the base asset.
*  IF the current quote asset amount is below my configured {min_quote_asset_amt}, the bot will place a Buy Taker order to exchange {quote_buy_amount} of the base asset for the quote asset.

After each {polling_rate}, I would like the bot to loop through checking the volatility of the pair and my current asset balances, then placing an order of the specified size until I have the specified minimum quantity of each asset.

_Gold plated super shiny version_

* has the following configuration options:
* min_base_asset_amt: [amount]
* min_quote_asset_amt: [amount]
* quote_sell_amt: [amount]
* quote_buy_amt: [amount]
* quote_sell_price_ceiling: [amount]
* quote_sell_price_floor: [amount]
* quote_buy_price_ceiling: [amount]
* quote_buy_price_floor: [amount]

This functions the same way as the minimum viable product version, with the following exceptions:

* If the price for the quote asset is above the {quote_sell_price_ceiling}, it will not be sold
* If the price for the quote asset is below the {quote_sell_price_floor}, it will not be sold
* If the price for the quote asset is above the {quote_buy_price_ceiling}, it will not be bought
* If the price for the quote asset is below the {quote_buy_price_floor}, it will not be bought

**Impact**
The desired behavior will allow me to balance my inventory to within a specified range so that I can gather rewards on both sides of a liquidity mining pair incentive. It will also allow me to automate the processes that I have been manually performing to best manage my bots instead of having to be awake and paying attention to make them all work most efficiently.

title: Randomize order_refresh_time

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

labels.name: strategy
labels.description: Strategies ideas

body:
**Feature Suggestion**
In order to make bots less discoverable and avoid user manipulation, it would be desirable to randomize order_refresh_time for all applicable strategies.
The way I think about this is by adding a relative "volatility" to the original mean value.

Example:

original order_refresh_time = 30 seconds
volatility = +/- 5 seconds

So then every time a new timer is set to refresh orders, the next timestamp is calculated based on normal distribution using mean=30 sec and sigma=5 sec.

1st refresh: 28sec
2nd: 31sec
3rd: 31sec
4th: 30sec
5th: 34sec
...

An active order ignores the `cancel_order_wait_time` parameter when the `end_datetime` has been reached. This leaves the chuck/s of the target order active until someone fills the order.

title: Standardize how configurations on strategies can be changed "on the fly"

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

body:
## To be implemented
A "flag" on strategy configurations that identify if that configuration can be changed on-the-fly (update the values without having to `stop` and restart the bot)

## Details
Some configurations on strategies can be changed without stopping the bot while others cannot.

The identified reason for that behavior is that the change of configuration values as the bot is running can end up messing up the whole strategy logic.

On previous strategy implementations (like on `pure_market_making`) each configuration was treated in isolation and there is no standard way to check if it would be possible to change the configuration value without breaking the normal bot behavior.

To make the development of new strategies more stream-lined, each configuration should have a boolean value defining if it can be changed with the bot running or not.

## Definition of done
* Implement a way to identify what configurations can be changed without stopping the bot
* Standardize the definition of when a config value can be changed or not

## Follow up tasks
* Refactor existing strategies configuration to follow this pattern

title: Update `PaperTradeExchange` to make use of new fields on `LimitOrder`

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Rewrite / restructure source code without affecting its behavior

body:
## Why
Initially, we did not have `filled_amount` which we think is the most important field. Because of that, partially filled orders in paper trade mode are not captured properly.

We also didn't have `creation_timestamp` for order age, what we have been doing so far is to extract it out of the order ID and revert back to the creation timestamp to calculate the order age which is not a good approach.

## What
Update `PaperTradeExchange` connector to store the new `creation_timestamp`, `filled_amount` and `status` correctly during order creation and updates.

* [ ] Partly filled order is stored and reported correctly, this can be done by create a large paper maker order on a low liquidity market.

title: Update MarketsRecorder and Connectors to support new `LimitOrder` fields

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Rewrite / restructure source code without affecting its behavior

body:
## Why
'creation_timestamp`, `filled_amount` and `status` have been added to LimitOrder. To make this data available to strategies and other parts of the system, we'll need to update MarketsRecorder, connectors and some other classes to store and propagate this new data.

## What
* Update `InflightOrderBase` to support the new fields: `creation_timestamp` is the timestamp when the inflight order object is created. 
* Update `HangingOrder` to include the new fields
* `MarketsRecorder` to store `creation_timestamp` on Order records (instead of db_timestamp)
* Update `BuyOrderCreatedEvent` and `SellOrderCreatedEvent` class to include `creation_timestamp` (this is so that MarketsRecorder can get this data)
* Update connectors (excluding PaperTradeExchange which is on a separated ticket) to include `creation_timestamp` when raising the order created events
* All inflight order child classes, update its `from_json` so that orders are created correctly once restored from database records

## Notes
* Since likely that not all connectors are going to be updated at the same in this task, the changes in this task should be backward compatible (assumes the new fields may not be populated)
* For the above reason, this task may not be worth taken on as the resource required (mainly testing) is huge but the main benefit of the change - make `filled_amount` available to strategies in case of partially filled orders - is small.

## DoD
* The new fields are now available to strategies (through limit_orders property).
* Orders are recorded correctly on Sqlite db

title: [Refactor] Update order age to calculate from `order.created_timestamp`

labels.name: refactor

body:
## Why
Currently, order age is calculated by extracting timestamp portion out of `client_order_id`. But this is not very neat and `PaperTrade` and `BackTest` connectors don't have timestamp on the ids. Since we are implementing #3622 we can calculate order age from `LimitOrder.creation_timestamp` (or use `age` function fo the LimitOrder). Though we'll still need to the existing calculation around as a backup since changes on `LimitOrder` might not yet be implemented on some connectors.

## What
Refactor below strategies where order age is calculated and displayed on status:

* Pure Market Making
* Perpetual Market Making
* Avellaneda Market Making

Refactor order age calculation in HangingOrdersTracker

## DoD
* The above mentioned strategies calculate order age first from `LimitOrder.creation_timestamp`. If the field is not populated, the age is calculated from `client_order_id` (as existing)
* Order age calculation is also updated in HangingOrdersTracker
* Unit tests for the changes

## Notes to QA
* This is a refactoring task, there is no new feature. You might want to test the strategies still report order age correctly.

title: Provide additional options for spot-perpetual-arbitrage to reduce liquidation risks

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

labels.name: strategy
labels.description: Strategies ideas

body:
**Feature Suggestion**
Provide an option in the spot-perpetual-arbitrage strategy to select between cross or isolated margin as well an option to define the amount of margin to use for isolated orders, similar to how we currently specify the order amount.

**Impact**
Currently, users of the spot-perpetual-arbitrage strategy run the risk of being liquidated because the bot places derivative orders using isolated margin. This is great for simple risk management but it exposes the trader to the risk of liquidation should positions stay open long enough to experience a somewhat large price movement.

**Additional context**
Perhaps this is an opportunity to improve documentation around this strategy, however, my understanding of spot-perpetual-arbitrage is that you are taking out two orders, one in spot and one on the derivative markets. These orders are opposite of one another (if spot is long, perpetual is short, and vice-versa), the spot order acting as the collateral for the perpetual contract. Eventually the prices of the two will converge below the convergence threshold configured for the bot and both deal will be closed. It is unclear, however, what happens when the perpetual position is liquidated before the prices converge.

Maybe this is where my understanding of the strategy needs improvement but It would seem to me that it would make sense to provide advanced options on spot-perpetual-arbitrage bots to either use cross leverage or a custom amount of margin to mitigate the possibility of this happening. If the risk of liquidation is not of concern, then I feel as though the documentation around the strategy should be clarified to indicate this.

title: Normalize balance_asset_limit behavior

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

body:
Currently, the bot ignores any prior PnL accumulated in a strategy when started with `start --restore`
Currently, the bot subtracts balance for placing hanging orders when started with `start --restore`

**Feature Suggestion**
Ideally, the bot would set:
`balance_asset_limit = balance_asset_limit + accumulated_PnL - fees_paid - hanging_order_balance `
for each asset, after a `start --restore`.

Alternatively, the bot would ignore the cost of placing hanging orders as far as `balance_asset_limit` is concerned. (Possibly a config setting?)

**Impact**
The desired behavior will allow me to `start --restore` a strategy after e.g. config changes, without having to manually account for prior trading activity by adjusting `balance_asset_limit`.

**Additional context**
Penalizing the base asset to place a hanging order, then giving 'free balance' to the quote asset when it fills seems inconsistent. (also, the inverse - depending on buy vs. sell). These quirks negate many advantages given by the option to limit the bot's access to account balances by increasing the human's workload on a `start --restore`.

title: External Price Module

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

labels.name: estimate
labels.description: Stories to be estimated

body:
**Why**
Trading strategies often need price information from external sources, external to the strategy but available within Hummingbot, for their trading activities whether market making, arbitraging and others.

**Feature Suggestion**
This module provides 4 types of price sources to choose from for any given trading pair:

1. Fixed price
    A static fixed conversion rate specified by the user
1. Rate Oracle
    Refers to preconfigured Rate Oracle for conversion rate
1. External Order Book
    Refers to an order book of any connector for pricing, can be further configured to provide 4 price types offered by an order book: mid price, best bid, best ask and last trade price
1. Custom API End Point
    Refers to user specified API URL end point which returns a decimal value

**Rate Oracle vs External Order Book**
When to use what

* External order book data is realtime, but limited to order books where we have a connector for.
* Rate oracle data can be lagging (depends on the oracle source) but it can give you any conversion rate as long as those symbols are available on the oracle source including when there is no order book for the pair.

**Impact**
This module can be used by any strategy, it needs to be configured before a strategy starts and stopped when the strategy stops. This plug-in module removes repetitive code currently on `arbitrage`, `cross_exchange_market_making` and `amm_arb` strategies. 

**Configurations**
The configuration settings for this module is saved as json as an embedded config to a trading strategy. 
For each trading pair in price_setting, these below configurations apply

`price_source`
Prompt: `What price source do you want to use for [base]-[quote] (fixed_rate, rate_oracle, external_order_book, custom_api)?`
Type: str

`fixed_conversion_rate`
Prompt: `Enter fixed price for [base] to [quote] >>>`
Type: Decimal
Prompted when: `fixed_rate` is chosen

`external_order_book_connector`
Prompt: `Enter a spot connector for [base]-[quote] order book >>>`
Type: str
Validate: the trading pair exists on the connector
Prompted when: `external_order_book` is chosen

`custom_api`
Prompt: `Enter an API URL for [base]-[quote] price >>>`
Type: str
Validation: The entered URL is valid and returns a decimal value
Prompted when: `custom_api` is chosen

**External Price setting confirmation**
When external price is used in a strategy, before the strategy starts the bot confirms if the setting is correct by displaying below messages for each trading pair
`[base]-[quote]`
`Price setting: [price_source]`
`[Other settings depending on price_source]`
`Price: [price]`

`Please confirm to proceed if the above setting is correct for this strategy (Yes/No)  >>> `
Note that price is not displayed when external order book price setting, this is bc the data is available only after the strategy starts.

**External order book**
When this option is configured, we can use paper trade connector to load up the external order book.

title: Fix race condition for _poll_notifier across all connectors

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Deprecate / code cleanup

labels.name: epic
labels.description: Collection of stories that runs through different sprints

body:
This issue was first identified in Issue #3449.

The bug arises when restarting a strategy. This is the result of insufficient stop procedure and a race condition that results in the connector being not ready; awaiting for the account balance to be updated.

This ticket serves as a master ticket to address this issue across **all** connectors. 
Note: Instead of a monolithic PR fixing all the connectors, we should prioritise certain connectors and schedule a fix for this bug accordingly.

The race condition is as described below:
**Scenario 1: (Delayed start)**

1. `tick()` gets called first:

* `self._poll_notifier.set()` 

1. `status_polling_loop()` gets called

* `self._poll_notifier = asyncio.Event()` <- resets the event
* `await self._poll_notifier.wait()` <- waits for event to be `.set()`

3.`tick()` gets called

* Only after the poll interval(after x mins) is reached, `.set()` is called

1. `status_polling_loop()` gets called

* proceeds to call `_update_balance()` 

**Scenario 2: (regular start)**

1. `status_polling_loop()` gets called first
  * `self._poll_notifier = asyncio.Event()` <- resets the event
  * `await self._poll_notifier.wait()` <- waits for event to be `.set()`
1. `tick()` gets called :
  * `self._poll_notifier.set()` 
1. `status_polling_loop()` gets called
  * proceeds to call `_update_balance()`

**Proposed Fix**

* Move the resetting of the `self._poll_notifier` event to after the `update_balance()` function is called.
* Resetting the relevant timestamps when `stop` command is issued
See PR #3474

title: Bitfinex - Balance allocated column not updating when there are open orders

**Describe the bug**
When running balance command on Bitfinex the allocated column is not taking into account open orders and only shows 0.

**Steps To Reproduce**

1. Connect Bitfinex in the client
1. Run a pure_market_making bot or manually place orders in the exchange
1. Once there are open orders already, run balance command

In this screenshot you'll see that I currently have open orders however the bot doesn't recognize those open orders and shows 0 in the allocated column when running balance command. Also notice the -0% that looks like a cosmetic bug.

title: Add more documentation to the hummingbot source code
body:
Hummingbot is an open source project and we want to welcome collaboration from outside the company.

1. Module level (top of each .py .pyx file) comments explaining the purpose of the file.
1. Function/method level comments.
1. Use pydoc to allow user to output it in a readable format. Think about hosting the output pydoc somewhere. https://docs.python.org/3/library/pydoc.html
1. Use the interrogate package to ensure a certain level of documentation https://interrogate.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

title: Add Liquidation warning event.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Upgrade or improvement to an existing hummingbot feature

body:
**Feature Suggestion**
There's currently no way for strategies to be notified of a possible liquidation.
Creating a liquidation warning event will fill in this gap and strategies can execute necessary logic to prevent a liquidation.

**Impact**
Modify derivative base class to include a function that constantly checks if active positions are close to being liquidated and trigger a liquidation warning event when necessary.

**To-do:**

* Create a global parameter called `liquidation_warning_margin_ratio`
* Create an event class for liquidation warning
* Create function which sends a trigger in the derivative base.
* Modify supported derivative connector to include the function and run infinitely as look as connector is being used.
* Add event listener for the new warning event in both strategies that support derivatives and execute necessary logic.

title: Design how to integrate Hummingbot with external signal providers

labels.name: research / design
labels.description: Related to research and design performed during off sprint

body:
(Originally Clubhouse story [9513](https://app.clubhouse.io/coinalpha/story/9513/design-how-to-integrate-hummingbot-with-external-signal-providers))

# Why
We are seeing increasing interest in integrating external signals or controls into Hummingbot. Some use cases that users want to enable are:

* integrating TradingView (most popular trader tool) with Hummingbot: https://coincise.co/how-to-send-commands-from-tradingview-to-hummingbot-telegram-account/
* integrating signals from analytics providers like IntoTheBlock into Hummingbot
* integrating [Twitch extensions](https://www.twitch.tv/p/extensions/) into Hummingbot to enable more streaming (our user QcPat has already started a [channel to steam Hummingbot](https://www.twitch.tv/crypto_trade)

The Twitch use case is less important than the other two, since we're not sure if streaming is something we want to promote.

# What
Design an approach to allow developers to integrate external signal providers like this into Hummingbot

* this is aimed at developers so no UI is needed
* signals can either be automated (predictive signals) or manual (Twitch/TradingView)
* since this will be an important long term aspect of the Hummingbot codebase, I think we should take the time to take through the architecture carefully
